DataElement.preferredName: Local Pathologic Diagnosis Meningioma Assessment Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The yes/no indicator for information related to the local pathologic diagnosis of meningioma.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the local pathologic diagnosis of meningioma.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

Property.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.:Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:A generally slow growing tumor attached to the dura mater. It is composed of neoplastic meningothelial (arachnoidal) cells. It typically occurs in adults, often women and it has a wide range of histopathological appearances. Of the various subtypes, meningothelial, fibrous and transitional meningiomas are the most common. Most meningiomas are WHO grade I tumors, and some are WHO grade II or III tumors. Most subtypes share a common clinical behavior, although some subtypes are more likely to recur and follow a more aggressive clinical course. (Adapted from WHO):The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.

A generally slow growing tumor attached to the dura mater. It is composed of neoplastic meningothelial (arachnoidal) cells. It typically occurs in adults, often women and it has a wide range of histopathological appearances. Of the various subtypes, meningothelial, fibrous and transitional meningiomas are the most common. Most meningiomas are WHO grade 1 tumors, and some are WHO grade 2 or 3 tumors. Most subtypes share a common clinical behavior, although some subtypes are more likely to recur and follow a more aggressive clinical course. (Adapted from WHO)
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
